articles.headline: Wall Street Is Back, Almost as Big as Ever
articles.snippet: Employment, compensation and mergers have all bounced back in the financial sector, and profits are not far from their 2007 highs.
articles.abstract: Employment, compensation and mergers have all bounced back in the financial sector, and profits are not far from their 2007 highs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Major investment banks have raised their standard base salary this spring for recent college graduates to $85,000, the first rise after five years in which the salaries hovered near $70,000.

articles.headline: Singapore’s Postal Service Reinvents Itself for the Digital Age
articles.snippet: With traditional mail fading, SingPost has transformed into a provider of logistics and marketing services to companies eager to tap the e-commerce boom in Asia.
articles.abstract: With traditional mail fading, SingPost has transformed into a provider of logistics and marketing services to companies eager to tap the e-commerce boom in Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — When a German lingerie brand wanted to sell bras online in Malaysia, it turned to Singapore’s nearly 200-year-old national postal service.

articles.headline: ‘Mad Men’ Finale Renews Spotlight on Creator of ’71 Coke Jingle
articles.snippet: The adman behind the Coke ad used in the series finale of “Mad Men” shares the true inspiration for the lyric, “I’d like to buy the world a Coke.”
articles.abstract: The adman behind the Coke ad used in the series finale of “Mad Men” shares the true inspiration for the lyric, “I’d like to buy the world a Coke.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Bill Backer lives on a farm in Virginia. He raises horses and cattle. When the weather gets cold, he and his wife of more than 30 years head to their small beach house in Florida, where they walk in the sun.

articles.headline: Regulators to Hold Hearing on Fiat Chrysler Safety Response
articles.snippet: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating 20 recalls covering more than 10 million vehicles.
articles.abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating 20 recalls covering more than 10 million vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a rare, sweeping move against an automaker, the nation’s top auto safety agency said on Monday that it was trying to determine whether Fiat Chrysler had failed to promptly fix safety defects in millions of recalled vehicles or properly notify owners.

articles.headline: Many Years of Overlooked Red Flags Catch Up to Stockbroker
articles.snippet: Jerry Cicolani’s record of 69 customer disputes is a case study of how long a broker can stay in business despite years of complaints.
articles.abstract: Jerry Cicolani’s record of 69 customer disputes is a case study of how long a broker can stay in business despite years of complaints.
articles.lead_paragraph: In most professions, it would take only one or two acts of egregious conduct before troubled employees were shown the door. In the case of one stockbroker who has repeatedly had complaints from investors, it took 69 customer disputes filed over the last 13 years before he was barred from the business.

articles.headline: Many on Wall Street Say It Remains Untamed
articles.snippet: In a report, many financial professionals said they knew of wrongdoing in the workplace. And even more found regulators ineffective in stopping it.
articles.abstract: In a report, many financial professionals said they knew of wrongdoing in the workplace. And even more found regulators ineffective in stopping it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street has changed. But perhaps not as much as you would think.

articles.headline: Critics Hear E.P.A.’s Voice in ‘Public Comments’
articles.snippet: Critics said a campaign by the E.P.A. to enlist public support for a proposal to protect the nation’s drinking water might have violated federal law on grass-roots lobbying.
articles.abstract: Critics said a campaign by the E.P.A. to enlist public support for a proposal to protect the nation’s drinking water might have violated federal law on grass-roots lobbying.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Environmental Protection Agency proposed a major new rule intended to protect the nation’s drinking water last year, regulators solicited opinions from the public. The purpose of the “public comment” period was to objectively gauge Americans’ sentiment before changing a policy that could profoundly affect their lives.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Coral Davenport

articles.headline: Anton Corbijn: Capturing the Mood of the Music
articles.snippet: Two shows, mounted in celebration of the photographer Anton Corbijn's 60th birthday, suggest the power of his work in defining a generation of musical stars.
articles.abstract: Two shows, mounted in celebration of the photographer Anton Corbijn's 60th birthday, suggest the power of his work in defining a generation of musical stars.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — For 40 years, the Dutch photographer and filmmaker Anton Corbijn has captured some of the most iconic rock musicians and other artists of our era — Bono, Mick Jagger, Björk, William S. Burroughs, Clint Eastwood — for magazines and books. So at first glance his conceptual series, “A. Somebody,” featuring what appear to be images of his personal musical heroes, doesn’t seem like a major departure.

articles.headline: 4 Cancer Charities Are Accused of Fraud
articles.snippet: A network of people controlled the “sham charities” and used a chunk of the more than $187 million in donations on personal expenses, regulators said.
articles.abstract: A network of people controlled the “sham charities” and used a chunk of the more than $187 million in donations on personal expenses, regulators said.
articles.lead_paragraph: There were subscriptions to dating websites, meals at Hooters and purchases at Victoria’s Secret — not to mention jet ski joy rides and couples’ cruises to the Caribbean.
